fields.description:
h2. Summary
Confluence application logs does not differentiate failed user *authentication* with failed *authorization*. Specifically:
# The logs record an incorrect warning when a user fails authentication due to invalid credentials
# The logs do not record any warning when a user passes authentication but cannot see content due to lack of authorization (no Global Permissions)
# The logs are only partially correct if a user who flat out does not exist tries to log in

This can lead to confusion for admins trying to debug why a user cannot use Confluence. The incorrect error message can lead to incorrect assumptions of global permissions and/or group membership configurations. The logs should be corrected and improved to provide more accurate messaging to administrators in each of the below scenarios.

{panel:titleBGColor=#3C78B5|titleColor=#FFFFFF|title=Scenario 1 - Failing Authentication}
h5. Steps to reproduce
# Create a user in Confluence
# In an incognito window, try to log in with this user but purposely use a wrong password

h5. Expected behavior
The logs should show that the user failed login due to incorrect credentials.

h5. Actual behavior
Logs show a message indicating the user lacks "USE" permission which implies authorization problem, but this is actually an authentication problem:
{code}
2017-09-14 11:20:02,569 WARN [http-nio-8090-exec-633] [atlassian.seraph.auth.DefaultAuthenticator] login login : 'myuser01' tried to login but they do not have USE permission or weren't found. Deleting remember me cookie.
{code}

h5. Other notes
The UI correctly shows "Sorry, your username and/or password are incorrect. Please try again."
{panel}

{panel:titleBGColor=#3C78B5|titleColor=#FFFFFF|title=Scenario 2 - Failing Authorization}
h5. Steps to reproduce
# Remove the test user from all groups in Global Permissions so that the account is not permitted to use Confluence
# In an incognito window, log in with this user using the correct credentials

h5. Expected behavior 
Since authentication passed but authorization failed, in this scenario we _should_ be logging something like:
{code}
User "myuser01" successfully authenticated but lacks CAN USE Global Permission.
{code}

h5. Actual behavior
Nothing is recorded in application logs

h5. Other notes
The UI correctly shows "Not Permitted"
{panel}

{panel:titleBGColor=#3C78B5|titleColor=#FFFFFF|title=Scenario 3 - User does not exist}
h5. Steps to reproduce
# In an incognito window, try to log in with a bogus username that does not exist

h5. Expected behavior
Logs should record something like:
{code}
User "myuser01" tried to authenticated, but this user does not exist in Confluence.
{code}

h5. Actual behavior
The same warning from Scenario 1 is logged, which is only partially correct ("weren't found"):
{code}
2017-09-14 11:20:02,569 WARN [http-nio-8090-exec-633] [atlassian.seraph.auth.DefaultAuthenticator] login login : 'myuser01' tried to login but they do not have USE permission or weren't found. Deleting remember me cookie.
{code}
{panel}
fields.summary: Incorrect logging when user fails authentication or authorization

fields.description:
We are developers of the Archiving Plugin for Confluence.

Our add-on batch-archives pages by moving them between spaces. Our customers frequently archive tens of thousands of pages in one go, sometimes even more. "Page move" does not need to be hyper-fast, but is expected to be complete in tens of minutes or in some hours most (overnight) even for this scale of data.

"Page move" has been a fairly fast operation in Confluence 5.7, and it became significantly slower some time between 5.7 and 5.10. (As far as I know the "Move page" feature has been rewritten in some Confluence version released around that time.)

Our profiling results:

|| Operation ||	1.014M pages in Confluence 5.7.6 || 5.8.18 metric ||	380K pages in Confluence 5.10.1 ||
| Page archiving with MOVE | 40 minutes (for 1555 pages) | N/A | 1.1 hours (for 400 pages - stable, but slower!) |

1555/40 = 39 page moved per minute in Confluence 5.7
400/66 = 6 page moved per minute in Confluence 5.10 

_6/39 means it is 85% slower than it used to be!_

Is there any chance to accelerate page moves in Confluence core? 
Or offer an API to batch-move multiple pages? (Currently, the API limits us to move one page at a time.)

**Update 02/06/2017**

Joint investigation by [~aron.gombas] and [~psemeniuk] (see comment thread below) showed that regression happened somewhere between 5.8.18 and 6.0.1:

|| || 5.8.0 || 5.8.18 || 6.0.1 ||
| Execution time | 23 m 10 s | 12 m 36 s | 23 m 53 s |

Regression is present both in memory consumption and cpu usage. As Aron proved increasing memory brings page move time by 30% but it still not up to par with what it was.

Possible area is either `DefaultRelatedContentRefactorer` class or it's clients.
fields.summary: "Move page" is 85% slower in Confluence 5.10+ than in 5.8.18, making moving large number of pages very inefficient

fields.description:
Hi,

We're slowly but surely molding confluence into a great system for our site and are now fine tuning performance. One thing we've noticed and sort of mitigated (in a good but not ideal way) is that whenever viewing a page a POST request get's made to synchrony/rest regardless of permissions... If the user has sufficient permissions they get a status 200 back and everything works fine. However if the user does not have sufficient permissions, it returns back a status 401. In different proxy / single-sign-on scenarios this can cause some difficulty and different products try "solve" this 401 which proved annoying. 

Initially it was through that it was another product calling this method as they were listed as the referrer/instigator in the web tools, however in a completely add-on-less testing instance this rest POST still tries to occur.

It took quite a bit of investigation to figure out that it was the confluence product AND confluence permissions that call call the method and cause that result (users with high access tend to also have high network access, making "permissions" as a whole the thing to troubleshoot).

The weird thing is that if a user who does not have edit rights will always fail and get 401's but they also will never get to the edit function which the one scenario where the method makes more sense. So I'm not sure what the synchrony/rest POST in a viewing window achieves? Are you able to explain why this occurs in a viewing session with no edit rights, and what it achieves? If it needs to occur, is it possible to detect permissions of the user and know that it will not succeed to stop an average user having 401's in their web session and/or logs?

I've attached an example of the code 200 response from the method.

!request.png!

Any answers around this would be great, as it was quite a "red herring" for our organization to narrow down and fix, and even after raises the question of why that method would even occur in that situation.

Kind Regards,

Kurt.
fields.summary: Confluence tries to perform a POST to synchrony/rest when user is viewing, regardless of permission?

JIRA macro does not load when a Custom Field is added as a Column to Display. After saving the page, the macro shows up as "loading issues" with a spinning wheel. When it finally fails, the error message can be seen as in the screenshot, and the macro is greyed out.
h3. How to replicate

Created blank page on brand new Confluence instance, added one JIRA Issues macro containing a custom field (A) and another without the custom field (B) - *Macros break*
Edited macro A in order to remove the custom field - *Macros break*
Removed macro A and inserted another macro without the custom field (C) - *Macros render properly*
Edited macro B in order to add the custom field - *Macros break*
h3. Expected results

Macros render correctly in all cases.
h3. Actual results

Macros fail when there's a custom field on them.

h3. Recommended Resolution

Upgrade to Confluence 7.7.4 or above, which contains a performance fix for Jira Issues Macro. This is detailed under CONFSERVER-56017.

Note that an initial attempt to fix the performance issue was made in Confluence versions 7.4.1 and 7.5.0. However, it caused other problems and was reverted in Confluence 7.4.3 and 7.6.2. A proper fix was introduced in Confluence 7.7.4.

19 Oct 2020 Update - For customers who would prefer to stay on long term support versions such as 7.4.x, Atlassian is currently looking into backporting the above fix to existing LTS release streams, so stay tuned.

h3. Workarounds

h4. Workaround - Increase Jira timeout (Confluence 7.4.1+)
[Set the system property|https://confluence.atlassian.com/doc/configuring-system-properties-168002854.html] {{confluence.jira.connection.timeout}} to a value higher than the default of 30000 (30 seconds)
This will increase the connection timeout for Confluence to fetch the results of a query from Jira.

h4. Workaround - Clean up Jira custom fields (all versions)
When Jira has a large number of custom fields, it can cause performance problems. [Cleaning up the custom fields|https://community.atlassian.com/t5/Jira-questions/What-is-best-way-to-delete-unused-custom-fields-from-JIRA-System/qaq-p/57790] that aren't used can improve performance.

h4. Workaround - Use Jira Filter Results Gadget instead (all versions)

If you are unable to upgrade, the Jira [Filter Results Gadget|https://confluence.atlassian.com/jira064/adding-the-filter-results-gadget-720416922.html] can be added to Confluence via [Registering External Gadgets|https://confluence.atlassian.com/doc/registering-external-gadgets-204050482.html] to load custom fields.
fields.summary: JIRA Issues macro fails with custom field

h3. Summary

It is not possible to connect with Synchrony if the domain starts with the letter "v" followed by a number. Example:

* v1test.com

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Set the domain to a pattern similar to *v1test.com* (v + number)
#* On UNIX systems, bind the IP to the domain in */etc/hosts*
# Set the Server Base URL to *v1test.com* in Confluence
# Try to access the editor

h3. Expected Results

The editor loads as expected.

h3. Actual Results

The browser cannot connect to Synchrony and you are unable to save the changes. Using the example URL, the portion of the domain after *v1* is "appended" to the URL. This causes the Synchrony resources to be unreachable as the URL changes to http://v1test.com/test.com:8091/synchrony:

 !edit-mode-error.png|thumbnail! 
 
h3. Notes

* Reviewing the application.xml, we can see that the Synchrony external URLs are correct:
{code}
<synchrony-external-url>http://v1test.com:8091/synchrony/v1</synchrony-external-url>
<synchrony-resources-url>http://v1test.com:8091/synchrony,http://v1test.com:8090/synchrony-proxy/resources</synchrony-resources-url>
{code}
* If we remove the appended portion of the domain, we can reach Synchrony as expected. The following URL returns an OK response:
{code}
http://v1test.com:8091/synchrony/heartbeat
{code}
* The requests to Synchrony resources in *View mode* are *not affected* by this bug (only in Edit mode):
 !view-mode.png|thumbnail! 
* The same problem happens with or without the internal Synchrony proxy
* The bug seems to happen only with the letter "v". If we use a1test.com, for example, we do not face this problem
* It could be related to the default external Synchrony URL, which includes *v1* at the end. E.g: http://v1test.com:8091/synchrony/v1

h3.Workaround

# Change the domain to avoid the offending pattern (v + number), or
# Disable Collaborative Editing if not able to change domain
fields.summary: The connection to Synchrony is not possible with specific domains

h3. Summary

When changing the value for {{confluence.home}} in {{confuence-init.properties}} after original installation, the backups still use the original value.
h3. Environment
 * Confluence 6.4.0

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Install Confluence 6.4.0 (either installer or manually)
 # Set Confluence up and compete configuration
 ** At this point manual and nightly backups will be in {{<confluence-home>/backups}}
 # Shutdown Confluence
 # Edit {{<confluence-install>/WEB-INF/classes/confluence-init.properties}} and change {{confluence.home}} to a new location
 # Move all the data from the original home directory to the new one
 # Create the directory {{<original-confluence-home>/backups}}
 # Restart Confluence
 # Go to  !https://confluence.atlassian.com/doc/files/590259974/590058056/1/1398739558493/Cog.png! > *General Configuration* > *Backup Administration* and confirm that the backup path is the new destination
 # Go to  !https://confluence.atlassian.com/doc/files/590259974/590058056/1/1398739558493/Cog.png! > *General Configuration* > *Backup & Restore*
 # Check *Archive to backups folder* and click *Back up*

Note now that we have the message
{panel}
An archive copy of the backup has been created at *<original-confluence-home>/backups/xmlexport-20170913-165125-3.zip.*
{panel}
And checking the directory we can see the file is in the original location still.
h3. Expected Results

The backup goes to the new home backups folder.
h3. Actual Results

The backup is dropped in the original backups folder.
h3. Notes

Using the XML export is not recommended as a production backup strategy
 * [Production Backup Strategy|https://confluence.atlassian.com/doc/production-backup-strategy-38797389.html]

The data is not changed in the bandana table
{code:sql}
select * from bandana where bandanakey ='atlassian.confluence.settings';
{code}
and look for {{<backupPath>...</backupPath>}}
h3. Workaround

Manually set the backup path via the steps in
 * [Configuring Backups - Enabling Backup Path Configuration|https://confluence.atlassian.com/doc/configuring-backups-138348.html#ConfiguringBackups-EnablingBackupPathConfiguration]

*This is an unsuported change*
 # Shutdown Confluence
 # Update the bananda table with a replace statement, for example
{code:sql}
update bandana set bandanavalue = replace(bandanavalue, '<backupPath>OLD BACKUP PATH</backupPath>', '<backupPath>NEW BACKUP PATH</backupPath>');
{code}
Where

 * {{OLD_BACKUP_PATH}} is something like {{/var/atlassian/application-data/confluence/backups}}
 * {{NEW_BACKUP_PATH}} is something like {{/mnt/confluence/backups}}

h3. Additional Note
* Moving from *Server* to *Data Center*, the backup path is not changed to "<shared-home>/backups" instead follows the old location "<local-home>/backups"
fields.summary: Backups use original home in confluence-init.properties after being changed

h3. Summary
If there are more than one group with System Administrator permissions, then the group *confluence-administrators* can be deleted. When re-adding the group the checkboxes for permissions cannot be changed (i.e. set to on)

 !ConfluenceAdministrators.png|thumbnail! 

h3. Environment
* Confluence 6.4.0

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Ensure there is more than one group with *System Administrator* permissions
## Go to !https://confluence.atlassian.com/doc/files/590259974/590058056/1/1398739558493/Cog.png! > *User Management* > *Groups*
## Create a new group *confluence-system-administrators*
## Click *Add Members* and add yourself
## Go to *Global Permissions*
## Click *Edit Permissions*
## Enter *confluence-system-administrators* to _Grant browse permission to_ and click Add
## Check all checkboxes *Personal Space*, *Create Space(s)*, *Confluence Administrator*, *System Administrator*
## Click *Save All* at the bottom
# Go to !https://confluence.atlassian.com/doc/files/590259974/590058056/1/1398739558493/Cog.png! > *User Management* > *Groups*
# Click Delete next to *confluence-administrators*
# Click Confirm
# Go to !https://confluence.atlassian.com/doc/files/590259974/590058056/1/1398739558493/Cog.png! > *User Management* > *Groups*
# (Re) Create a new group *confluence-administrators*
# Click *Add Members* and add yourself
# Go to *Global Permissions*
# Click *Edit Permissions*
# Enter *confluence-administrators* to _Grant browse permission to_ and click Add

The checkboxes for *Personal Space*, *Create Space(s)*, *Confluence Administrator*, *System Administrator* are now greyed out and cannot be clicked.

h3. Expected Results
Either
* The checkboxes for *Personal Space*, *Create Space(s)*, *Confluence Administrator*, *System Administrator* can be clicked.
* The group *confluence-administrators* should not be deletable.

h3. Actual Results
The checkboxes for *Personal Space*, *Create Space(s)*, *Confluence Administrator*, *System Administrator* are now greyed out and cannot be clicked.

 !ConfluenceAdministrators.png|thumbnail! 

 
h3. Notes
The check boxes are not changable because *confluence-administrators* is a super-super user group. And so the permissions should not be changed. Thus, the group should not be deletable.

h3.Workaround 
The SQL for the permissions needs to be re-inserted.  This may cause issues later if there is a collision with the *permid* value.
# Create the group *confluence-administrators* via the UI
# Shutdown Confluence
# Run this SQL (this is for PostgreSQL)
{code:sql}
insert into spacepermissions (permid, permtype, permgroupname, creationdate, lastmoddate) values (1000, 'CREATESPACE', 'confluence-administrators', current_timestamp, current_timestamp);
insert into spacepermissions (permid, permtype, permgroupname, creationdate, lastmoddate) values (1001, 'PERSONALSPACE', 'confluence-administrators', current_timestamp, current_timestamp);
insert into spacepermissions (permid, permtype, permgroupname, creationdate, lastmoddate) values (1002, 'SYSTEMADMINISTRATOR', 'confluence-administrators', current_timestamp, current_timestamp);
insert into spacepermissions (permid, permtype, permgroupname, creationdate, lastmoddate) values (1003, 'ADMINISTRATECONFLUENCE', 'confluence-administrators', current_timestamp, current_timestamp);
{code}
# Restart Confluence
fields.summary: Group confluence-administrators Should Not Be Deletable

h3. Summary
If you attach and save too many MP4 files to a page using the multimedia macro, not all video files display or play back correctly.  This behavior occurred using Chrome 59.0.3071.115 (Official Build) (64-bit) while it does not happen in Firefox or Safari.  Also, this same page had previously worked in Confluence 5.7.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Restored a space XML export from a customer that contained a page with 14 MP4 files attached via the Multimedia macro, 

h3. Actual Results
# # Using a Chrome browser, I performed the following tests:
##  When I first opened the page, a blank white space was displayed in each section of the page where you used the Media Macro to embed the MP4 videos. Additionally, if I clicked the play button for a video, nothing would happen as the browser displayed a "Processing request" message at the bottom of the browser window.  Furthermore, the page continually clocked as if it were stuck loading content. This occurred for over 10 minutes with no change in the display of the video content.
## However, when I reloaded the page, let it clock, and then hit the 'X' to stop page load, the behavior changed. The video splash images for all of the videos on the page would appear and if I hit the play button, the video would play.
## Along with these tests, I tried to create a HAR file to inspect the page requests that occurred when opening the page. While I could see 206 Partial Content error messages for each of the video files, the resulting HAR file was not viewable in a HAR viewer and there were no other errors listed.
## Next, I saved off each video to my file system and created a new page in a new space and embedded all of the videos using the media macro. Initially, the page displayed all videos with no problem. But, after leaving this new page and returning to it after a short while, the video splash images would not appear and clicking the play button did nothing. This behavior was exactly like that which I observed with your page.
## As a final test, I removed several of the embedded videos from my new page. The result? The page started displaying all of the embedded videos again.

h3. Expected Results
Expected behavior is for the video splash images to display and be playable when the page opens up.

h3. Workaround
There appears to be two workarounds.  
# One way would be to remove several of the videos until the page starts displaying all embedded videos again.  
# A second way, which doesn't always work, hit the 'X' in the URL bar to stop the page load and then click on refresh.

fields.description:
h4. Issue Summary
The [Confluence Chart Macro|https://confluence.atlassian.com/doc/chart-macro-163415075.html] can be rendered based on the input of tables. Inside these tables that will serve to render the Chart Macro, instead of typing numbers, customers usually rely on JIRA Macros to get a count of issues based on JQL Queries, using this count as input for the tables and consequently as input for the Chart Macro. This is a problem when using Confluence 5.10.8 Version, since the chart does not render anymore when using the above mentioned combination.

h4. Replication Environment
Confluence 5.8.6 - Clean Instance.
Confluence 5.10.8 - Clean Instance.
JIRA 7.2.7 - Clean Instance.

h4. Replication Steps
# Open your JIRA Instance and create three issues. Assign one of them and leave the other two unassigned. We will use this scenario to replicate the issue, however, you can setup JIRA as you want, as long as there are issues there to query.
# Create an Application Link between your Confluence 5.10.8 and JIRA 7.2.7.
# Once that's done, create a Test Page in your Confluence 5.10.8.
# Insert the Chart Macro in the Page.
# For explanation purposes, select Type = Bar and Display Orientation = Vertical.
# Hit the Show in 3D Check-Box.
# Save it.
# Now, inside the Chart Macro Area, insert a 2x3 Table.
# Name it as below Screenshot:
 !PS-15992 - Table.png|thumbnail! 
# Right next to the 'Two Issues' column, insert the Jira Charts Macro. On its Dialog Box, select Jira Issue/Filter option.
# Search using the following filter:
{code}
project = HTP AND issuetype = Bug AND status = "To Do" AND assignee in (EMPTY)
{code}
# Click on Display Options and select the combo box called 'Total Issue Count' and then hit Insert.
# Right next to the 'One Issue' column, insert the Jira Charts Macro. On its Dialog Box, select Jira Issue/Filter option.
# Search using the following filter:
{code}
project = HTP AND issuetype = Bug AND status = "To Do" AND assignee not in (EMPTY)
{code}
# Click on Display Options and select the combo box called 'Total Issue Count' and then hit Insert.
# At this point, your Editor should be looking like this - Screenshot is showing a 'X' instead of a number because JIRA was offline during the screenshot capture time:
 !Screen Shot 2017-09-07 at 18.17.55.png|thumbnail! 
# Save the Page. The Chart won't render and will be looking like below:
 !Screen Shot 2017-09-01 at 19.34.49.png|thumbnail! 

h4. Expected Behaviour
Repeat above steps using Confluence 5.8.6 instead of Confluence 5.10.8 and it will work fine. It should look like this:
 !Screen Shot 2017-09-07 at 18.21.01.png|thumbnail! 

h4. Differences in between the Versions
* Confluence 5.8.6 uses the following versions:
{code:java}
<plugin>
    <key>confluence.extra.chart</key>
    <name>Chart Plugin</name>
    <version>2.0.5</version>
    <vendor>Atlassian Pty Ltd</vendor>
    <status>ENABLED</status>
    <vendor-url>http://www.atlassian.com/</vendor-url>
    <framework-version>2</framework-version>
    <bundled>Bundled</bundled>
</plugin>
{code}
{code:java}
<plugin>
  <key>confluence.extra.jira</key>
  <name>JIRA Macros</name>
  <version>5.6.12</version>
  <vendor>Atlassian Pty Ltd</vendor>
  <status>ENABLED</status>
  <vendor-url>http://atlassian.com</vendor-url>
  <framework-version>2</framework-version>
  <bundled>Bundled</bundled>
</plugin>
{code}
* While Confluence 5.10.8 uses the following plugin versions:
{code:java}
<plugin>
    <key>confluence.extra.chart</key>
    <name>Chart Plugin</name>
    <version>2.1.1</version>
    <vendor>Atlassian Pty Ltd</vendor>
    <status>ENABLED</status>
    <vendor-url>http://www.atlassian.com/</vendor-url>
    <framework-version>2</framework-version>
	<bundled>Bundled</bundled>
</plugin>
{code}
{code:java}
 <plugin>
    <key>confluence.extra.jira</key>
    <name>Confluence JIRA Plugin</name>
    <version>6.0.11</version>
    <vendor>Atlassian Pty Ltd</vendor>
    <status>ENABLED</status>
    <vendor-url>http://atlassian.com</vendor-url>
    <framework-version>2</framework-version>
	<bundled>Bundled</bundled>
</plugin>
{code}

h4. Workarounds
There are two workaround for this case. You can either add a Dark Feature to disable JIRA Macro async render or you can downgrade the plugins version. First option is strongly recommended.

h5. Option 1 - Dark Feature
# Access the following URL: http://<Confluence-Base-URL>/admin/darkfeatures.action
# Add the following Site Dark feature and save:
{code}
confluence.extra.jira.async.loading.disable
{code}
# There's no need to restart your application, just try accessing your page again and it should work fine.

h5. Option 2 - Downgrade Plugin Version
(!) This workaround was tested in a clean instance and no side effects were observed. However, in an enterprise instance, it is interesting to first apply this workaround to a test instance first and observe it for any side effects.

*Objective:* 
Downgrade JIRA Macros from version 6.0.11 to version 5.6.12.

*How to:* 
# Stop Confluence.
# Access {{Confluence-Instalation-Directory/confluence/WEB-INF/atlassian-bundled-plugins}} on Confluence 5.10.8 and delete the {{confluence-jira-plugin-6.0.11.jar}} file after backing-up the above mentioned folder.
# Access {{Confluence-Instalation-Directory/confluence/WEB-INF/atlassian-bundled-plugins}} on Confluence 5.8.6 and copy the {{confluence-jira-plugin-5.6.12.jar}} file.
# Paste it to {{Confluence-Instalation-Directory/confluence/WEB-INF/atlassian-bundled-plugins}} on Confluence 5.10.8.
# [Clear Plugin Cache|https://confluence.atlassian.com/confkb/how-to-clear-confluence-plugins-cache-297664846.html].
# Start Confluence.
# Charts will render properly.
fields.summary: Chart Macro with JIRA Macro Issue Count does not render properly

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
*NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Server*. Using *Confluence Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFCLOUD-32555].
{panel}
h2. General Description

When you invite a user or group to edit a page, there is no sanity check or confirmation in place to verify that this won't cause a large amount of spam to users.
{panel:title=Example}
Example: If there is a group called "{{all}}" and someone attempts to invite "{{Allison}}" to invite a page, they may instead invite everybody in the "{{all}}" group, which could be potentially thousands of users. Same thing for email as well. 
{panel}
h2. References

In our [Release Notes for 6.2 Notes|https://confluence.atlassian.com/doc/confluence-6-2-release-notes-894219485.html], it notes that you can invite any user, or email, or group to edit.

*There is no known workaround to prevent this behavior from happening other than removing the permissions to invite for a given Confluence user.*
h2. Suggestions

This feature request to add some type of "hey, wait a minute" confirmation dialog or restriction to prevent these kinds of issues.
h3. Possible things to add
 - add a confirmation dialog that tells them explicitly that their action will send an email to the users and/or groups selected with the consequences
 - add a configurable threshold to disallow inviting more than X users or groups with more than Y users in a given timeframe (invite flood protection)
 - enhance permissions (per CONFSERVER-7089 ) in order to let users only invite users and not groups or emails (or some combination thereof)

h2. Steps to reproduce
 * Create a page and publish it.
 * Observe the time on the collaborator relations on the page.
 * Update the page and publish it.
 * Check the time on the collaborator relationships on the old version of the page. It shows the current time instead of the original time.

h2. Explanation and actual behaviour

Because of the way versioning works in Confluence, during a page publish we:
 * Create a copy of the latest published version of the page
 * Create the collaborator relationships on the new page object which has the old published version of the page
 * Update the current version of the page in place

[^atlassian-oauth-service-provider-plugin-2.0.4.jar] 
# Paste it inside _<Confluence-Installation-Directory>/confluence/WEB-INF/atlassian-bundled-plugins_ folder.
# [Clear plugin cache|https://confluence.atlassian.com/confkb/how-to-clear-confluence-plugins-cache-297664846.html].
